posts.name: Doruk Yıldırım
posts.cooked: Hi all! We are going to make a dashboard for this season and we were wondering which framework should we base ours on? (Shuffleboard, SmartDashboard, Glass, LabVIEW, Dashboard)

link_counts.title: What are smart dashboard, shuffleboard, and phoenix tuner used for?

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked:
Ultimately it’s up to you and your team what meets your needs best.  SmartDashboard and Shuffleboard are only receiving minimal updates (i.e. make sure they work, but no new features) since the person who originally wrote it for wpilib has since moved on to other things.  Both work quite well, though Shuffleboard is a bit more customizable.

Default LabVIEW dashboard is stable but doesmt probide much in terms of customization.  This can be resolved by building your own dashboard in LabVIEW, but if youre a Java/C++/Python/etc team, that would be quite the undertaking for little (if any) gain over the alternatives.

Glass is a newer thing.  I haven’t personally used it, so I’m unable to intelligently comment on it at this time.

posts.name: Kellen Watt
posts.cooked:
My understanding is that Glass is more intended for development purposes, and less for competition. It’s UI/UX is not particularly friendly for the quick pace of matches (e.g. for boolean information, a big green or red light is way easier to understand than text).

That said, this is from reading the docs . I’ve never used it personally, precisely for these reasons, so I welcome the input of anyone with more experience than me.

link_counts.title: Introduction to Glass — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Doruk Yıldırım
posts.cooked: Understood, looks don’t matter to us because ultimately its functionality that matters so Glass would be a no-go, thanks!

posts.name: Doruk Yıldırım
posts.cooked: We are looking for a reliable and frequently updated framework so I’m kinda leaning towards the default LabView dashboard. However we are a java team so how much of a challenge you think this is going to be? and what would be our limitations?

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked: “frequently updated” would definitely not include the default labview one… That’s been pretty much identical for years.  As a java team, I would recommend Shuffleboard (at least as far as officially supported ones go).  It’s stable and does most anything you’ll need, though don’t expect much in terms of NEW features.

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked: Yeah, this was my understanding as well.  Guess I forgot to include that.  Thanks for the info!

posts.name: Doruk Yıldırım
posts.cooked: I understand, I’ve played around with Shuffleboard for a bit now and I actually like it pretty much. I thonk that’s what we’re going to stick with. Thanks!

posts.name: Chris
posts.cooked: If you’re interested in a more custom solution, there are quite a few teams who use web-based dashboards. I wrote this library for the new NetworkTables protocol and it works really nicely with React

link_counts.title: Ntcore-ts-client: A TypeScript library for NetworkTables 4.0 - Programming - Chief Delphi

posts.name: NewtonCrosby
posts.cooked:
Have any teams up up the dashboard side of things as a library yet?

I don’t know UI code very well at all, would love to see someone open source a generic dashboard that can build boolean box widgets, etc.  Outside of my skill set for sure.

posts.name: Weaver Goldman
posts.cooked: We have made a lot of progress with our own custom solution recently, but we don’t have enough dedicated programmers to make this happen right now. Maybe during the offseason we can make a generic version.

posts.name: Kellen Watt
posts.cooked: That’s pretty much my team’s plan right now too. First to the finish then!

posts.name: Cr1spyBacon8r
posts.cooked: We’re doing a custom web dashboard this year, now that NT4 has native websockets support. I might work on making a generic setup to make it easier for others to build their own, but for now, ours is built as a setup that’s not very user friendly to develop on top of.

posts.name: Weaver Goldman
posts.cooked: Lol I’ll pass that challenge on to the younger programmers.

posts.name: Cr1spyBacon8r
posts.cooked: I actually just made a wrapper for this library, making it even easier to use for React. GitHub - CrispyBacon1999/ntcore-react: Quickly connect your React App to NetworkTables . The API you provided is awesome to work with!

link_counts.title: GitHub - CrispyBacon1999/ntcore-react: Quickly connect your React App to NetworkTables

posts.name: AmoryG
posts.cooked:
There’s an open source dashboard called FRC Web Components I’ve been working on:

It has most of the same widgets from shuffleboard, plus a plugin system so you can build and add your own custom components/widgets to the dashboard (it’s web-based so you’ll need to know javascript/html/css if you want to build plugins). It hasn’t seen any real competition use, although my team is using it for a week 0 event. Still plenty of work to be done but you can download the app here if you’d like to give it a try: Releases · frc-web-components/app · GitHub

Docs are still a WIP: GitHub - frc-web-components/frc-web-components at version4

link_counts.title: Yet Another Generic Swerve Library (YAGSL) Beta

posts.name: Chris
posts.cooked: Dude!! This is great! I’m going to mess around with this tomorrow

I’ve integrated NT4 into Scratch so Scratch variables automatically double as NT keys.

I’m curious to see if it’ll be easier for my students (especially non programming ones) to make fully custom dashboards and visualizers this way.

This uses @gerthworm 's NT impl. @Chris2fourlaw I tried yours but it doesn’t seem to support multiple NT connections (I make an NT Client for sim and for the robot and auto-switch between giving priority to sim)

posts.name: Chris
posts.cooked: Yeah you’re right, multiple connections don’t work. I’ll work on this feature, thanks!
